They're tiny animals that grow
up to one millimeter long,
and have eight legs.
They're also known as water bears.

Some speculate that there
are around 900 known species.
They were given the name Tardigrada,
by Italian biologist Lazarro Spallanzani.

They're also known as
moss piglets. (pig grunt)

They typically live
around water and damp moss

or lichens, but can be found
almost everywhere on Earth.

Some theorize they might
have come from space,
of course, this is just a theory.

They can survive dry periods
by curling into little balls.

They can hang around
like that for 100 years,
before casually regenerating.
Some species are carnivorous.
Some might even eat other Tardigrades.
So, how resilient are these little guys?

They can withstand 1,000
times the lethal human dose
of X-ray radiation.
In 2007, some Tardigrades hitched a ride

on a space shuttle and
lived outside the spacecraft
in an oxygen-deprived vacuum of space
for 10 days.
Many survived.

All of which means,
it's probably impossible
to kill a Tardigrade.
